lines.line_text: DEAR S****, the sleest, pawkie thief,
That e'er attempted stealth or rief,
For ne'er a bosom yet was prief

stanzas.stanza_text:
DEAR S****, the sleest, pawkie thief,
That e'er attempted stealth or rief,
Ye surely hae some warlock-breef
Owre human hearts;
For ne'er a bosom yet was prief
Against your arts.

lines.line_text: For me, I swear by sun an' moon,
And ev'ry star that blinks aboon,
Ye've cost me twenty pair o' shoon
And ev'ry ither pair that's done,

stanzas.stanza_text:
For me, I swear by sun an' moon,
And ev'ry star that blinks aboon,
Ye've cost me twenty pair o' shoon
Just gaun to see you;
And ev'ry ither pair that's done,
Mair taen I'm wi' you.

lines.line_text: To mak amends for scrimpet stature,
She's turn'd you off, a human-creature
And in her freaks, on ev'ry feature,

stanzas.stanza_text:
That auld, capricious carlin, Nature,
To mak amends for scrimpet stature,
She's turn'd you off, a human-creature
On her first plan,
And in her freaks, on ev'ry feature,
She s wrote, the Man.

lines.line_text: Just now I've taen the fit o' rhyme,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Just now I've taen the fit o' rhyme,
My barmie noddle's working prime,
My fancy yerket up sublime
Wi' hasty summon:
Hae ye a leisure-moment's time
To hear what's comin?

lines.line_text: Some rhyme a neebor's name to lash;
Some rhyme, (vain thought!) for needfu' cash;
Some rhyme to court the countra clash,
For me, an aim I never fash;
The star that rules my luckless lot,
Has fated me the russet coat,
An' damn'd my fortune to the groat;
Has blest me with a random-shot

stanzas.stanza_text:
The star that rules my luckless lot,
Has fated me the russet coat,
An' damn'd my fortune to the groat;
But, in requit,
Has blest me with a random-shot
O' countra wit.

lines.line_text: This while my notion's taen a sklent,
To try my fate in guid, black prent;
But still the mair I'm that way bent,
" I red you, honest man, tak tent!

stanzas.stanza_text:
This while my notion's taen a sklent,
To try my fate in guid, black prent;
But still the mair I'm that way bent,
Something cries, "Hoolie!
" I red you, honest man, tak tent!
Ye'll shaw your folly.

lines.line_text: " Far seen in Greek, deep men o' letters,
"Hae thought they had ensur'd their debtors,

stanzas.stanza_text:
"There's ither Poets, much your betters,
" Far seen in Greek, deep men o' letters,
"Hae thought they had ensur'd their debtors,
" A' future ages;
"Now moths deform in shapeless tatters,
" Their unknown pages. "

lines.line_text: Henceforth, I'll rove where busy ploughs
An' teach the lanely heights an' howes

stanzas.stanza_text:
Then farewel hopes of Laurel-boughs,
To garland my poetic brows!
Henceforth, I'll rove where busy ploughs
Are whistling thrang,
An' teach the lanely heights an' howes
My rustic sang.

lines.line_text: I'll wander on with tentless heed,
Till fate shall snap the brittle thread;
I'll Iay me with th' inglorious dead,

stanzas.stanza_text:
I'll wander on with tentless heed,
How never-halting moments speed,
Till fate shall snap the brittle thread;
Then, all unknown,
I'll Iay me with th' inglorious dead,
Forgot and gone!

lines.line_text: But why, o' Death, begin a tale?
Just now we're living sound an' hale;
Then top and maintop croud the sail,

stanzas.stanza_text:
But why, o' Death, begin a tale?
Just now we're living sound an' hale;
Then top and maintop croud the sail,
Heave Care o'er-side!
And large, before Enjoyment's gale,
Let's tak the tide.

lines.line_text: This life, sae far's I understand,
Maks Hours like Minutes, hand in hand,

stanzas.stanza_text:
This life, sae far's I understand,
Is a' enchanted fairy-land,
Where Pleasure is the Magic-wand,
That, wielded right,
Maks Hours like Minutes, hand in hand,
Dance by fu' light.

lines.line_text: The magic-wand then let us wield;
For, ance that five an' forty's speel'd,
Comes hostan, hirplan owre the field,

stanzas.stanza_text:
The magic-wand then let us wield;
For, ance that five an' forty's speel'd,
See, crazy, weary, joyless Eild,
Wi' wrinkl'd face,
Comes hostan, hirplan owre the field,
Wi' creeping pace.

lines.line_text: When ance life's day draws near the gloamin,
O Life! how pleasant in thy morning,
Young Fancy's rays the hills adorning!
Like school-boys, at th' expected warning,

stanzas.stanza_text:
O Life! how pleasant in thy morning,
Young Fancy's rays the hills adorning!
Cold-pausing Caution's lesson scorning,
We frisk away,
Like school-boys, at th' expected warning,
To joy and play.

lines.line_text: We wander there, we wander here,
We eye the rose upon the brier,
Unmindful that the thorn is near,
And tho' the puny wound appear,

stanzas.stanza_text:
We wander there, we wander here,
We eye the rose upon the brier,
Unmindful that the thorn is near,
Among the leaves;
And tho' the puny wound appear,
Short while it grieves.

lines.line_text: Some, lucky, find a flow'ry spot,
For which they never toil'd nor swat;
They drink the sweet and eat the fat,
And haply, eye the barren hut,
With steady aim, Some Fortune chase;
Keen hope does ev'ry sinew brace;
Thro' fair, thro' foul, they urge the race,
Then canie, in some cozie place,
And others, like your humble servan',
Poor wights! nae rules nor roads observin;
To right or left, eternal swervin,
Till curst with Age, obscure an' starvin,
Alas! what bitter toil an' straining —
But truce with peevish, poor complaining!
Beneath what light she has remaining,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Alas! what bitter toil an' straining —
But truce with peevish, poor complaining!
Is Fortune's fickle Luna waning?
E'en let her gang!
Beneath what light she has remaining,
Let's sing our Sang.

lines.line_text: My pen I here fling to the door,
And kneel, 'Ye Pow'rs, and warm implore,
' Tho' I should wander Terra o'er,
' Grant me but this, I ask no more,

stanzas.stanza_text:
My pen I here fling to the door,
And kneel, 'Ye Pow'rs, and warm implore,
' Tho' I should wander Terra o'er,
'In all her climes,
' Grant me but this, I ask no more,
'Ay rowth o' rhymes.

lines.line_text: ' Gie fine braw claes to fine Life-guards,
' And yill an' whisky gie to Cairds,
'While ye are pleas'd to keep me hale,
' I'll fit down o'er my scanty meal,
' As lang's the Muses dinna fail

stanzas.stanza_text:
'While ye are pleas'd to keep me hale,
' I'll fit down o'er my scanty meal,
'Be't water-brose, or muslin-kail,
' Wi' chearfu' face,
' As lang's the Muses dinna fail
'To say the grace.

lines.line_text: An anxious e'e I never throws
Behint my lug, or by my nose;
Sworn foe to sorrow, care, and prose,
O ye, douse folk, that live by rule,
Compar'd wi' you — O fool! fool! fool!
Your hearts are just a standing pool,

stanzas.stanza_text:
O ye, douse folk, that live by rule,
Grave, tideless-blooded, calm and cool,
Compar'd wi' you — O fool! fool! fool!
How much unlike!
Your hearts are just a standing pool,
Your lives, a dyke!

Nae hare-brain'd, sentimental traces,
In your unletter'd, nameless faces!
In arioso trills and graces
Ye never stray,
But gravissimo, solemn basses
Ye hum away.

lines.line_text: Ye are sae grave, nae doubt ye're wise;
Nae ferly tho' ye do despise
I see ye upward cast your eyes —

stanzas.stanza_text:
Ye are sae grave, nae doubt ye're wise;
Nae ferly tho' ye do despise
The hairum-scairum, ram-stam boys,
The rambling squad:
I see ye upward cast your eyes —
— Ye ken the road —

lines.line_text: Whilst I — but I shall haud me there —
Wi' you I'll scarce gang ony where —
Then Jamie, I shall say nae mair,
Content with YOU to mak a pair,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Whilst I — but I shall haud me there —
Wi' you I'll scarce gang ony where —
Then Jamie, I shall say nae mair,
But quat my sang,
Content with YOU to mak a pair,
Whare'er I gang.
